poem:
Red at the Funeral

Most of them wore black,
as if the day itself required a uniform,
as if grief came only in one color.

But somewhere among the shoulders and dark coats,
a red scarf, a red suit,
a memory refusing to be dimmed,

like that old woman at the opera
standing in the crowd
the way a match stands up in a drawer.
